metadata.title: Interesting AI/ML Articles You Should Read This Week (Aug 22) | by Richmond Alake | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Interesting AI/ML Articles You Should Read This Week (Aug 22)
metadata.description: So I did what most of you would do, I purchased books on PyTorch and TensorFlow, watched videos and read tons of Medium articles. Chris Lovejoy writes about learnings from the experience of…

all_paragraphs: Around a year ago, I was approaching the end of my MSc in Machine Learning and Computer Vision.
Although I had gained some useful theoretical knowledge, my practical experience was still lacking.
So I did what most of you would do, I purchased books on PyTorch and TensorFlow, watched videos and read tons of Medium articles.
“You’re only as good as your top three projects” — Chris Lovejoy
Chris Lovejoy writes about learnings from the experience of transitioning from a career in the medical field to a machine learning related profession.
Chris first advice to individuals looking to make a career change from a non-technical profession is to network.

The article points out common pitfalls early developer tend to fall into. These pitfalls can be avoided by seeking assistance from seasoned developers. According to Chris, he found technical guidance by meeting individuals at tech events, meetups and reaching out through LinkedIn.

Having a stellar portfolio is age-old advice within the technological industry. Still, Chris provides actionable steps that can be taken to accumulate a series of projects for portfolios. From attending project-based courses to hackathons, it seems Chris has utilised all possibilities of gaining ideas for his projects.

Bootcamps has quickly become a fast route for individuals coming from unconventional backgrounds to have the necessary skillset to survive within a tech-based role. The article includes a short personal account of Chris’s experience in a Bootcamp and incorporates details on the Bootcamp and price.
Machine learning related professions have an ongoing learning process. Ideally, the key to success is to understand the fundamentals, and this is the message Chris is sending to readers.
Chris provides a couple of links that point to learning resources geared towards maths and a summary of theoretical topics that aspiring Data Scientists should have expertise within.

Taking an MSc is the traditional method of gaining knowledge within a specialised domain. According to Chris, there was difficulty in been taken seriously without the intention of undertaking an MSc in Data Science.

There are a lot of articles geared towards individuals with technical background transitioning into machine learning related roles. Chris account is different and appeals to individuals with non-technical backgrounds.
A brief introduction to Super Resolution and its applications.

Shivani Rapole provides a simple explanation to a topic that most would find daunting through the use of relatable use cases and well-described scenarios that justify technical approaches. This topic is Super Resolution.

Super Resolution(SR) is a technique that is applied to a large number of industries and applications. Shivani informs the reader of some typical applications of SR by providing brief details on how SR can be utilised in various use cases.
This article isn’t a comprehensive background into the inner workings of SR, which is why I would recommend this article as either an information source or a refresher article.
Readers will need to supplement knowledge gained from this article with external sources.
That been said, Shivani provides an overview of Super-Resolution without the inclusion of algorithms or complicated images makes this article an excellent resource for machine learning students.
An invaluable resource of video content on Deep Learning topics for machine learning enthusiast and students
Andreas Maier is a professor at FAU Germany and has written a compilation article of deep learning topics presented through blogs and videos.
Readers can see this article as a content page to various deep learning topics such as neural networks, reinforcement learning, object detection etc.

There are 15 Chapters covered, and each chapter is accompanied by an image depicting course content. Chapters are partitioned into sections that are supplemented with resource links that point to video content and lecture notes.
For machine learning students and readers, this is an opportunity to receive University level education at no cost at all.
A practical introduction to Recurrent Neural Network with PyTorch
Nishil Madhani has written a short but useful guide to understanding the implementation of recurrent neural networks in PyTorch.

In the real world, data takes on various forms and sizes. Outputs of applications that receive a variety of inputs, also have variability in their sizes. Taking this into consideration, we require flexibility in the type of data a neural network can process and produce. Recurrent neural networks (RNN) meet this requirement.
Nishil provides a descriptive overview of a typical RNN architecture that is supplemented with an illustrated schematic diagram.

This beginner-friendly article explains technical terms and libraries utilised to implement and train an RNN. There are some prerequisites required to be able to follow the article’s content, but a quick Google search should provide readers with the required knowledge.
This article explores the following topics, tools and subject areas: Python, PyTorch, Deep Learning, Time Series Prediction, Recurrent Neural Networks, Numpy, etc.
To connect with me or find more content similar to this article, do the following:
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Machine Learning Content Creator with 1M+ views— Computer Vision Engineer. Interested in gaining and sharing knowledge on Technology and Finance
